titleStmt.title: The Consciences — the Moral one
a machine readable transcription

address.addrLine: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities

availability.p: The text of the original document is in the public domain. Subject to certain exceptions, public domain works may be freely copied or used in the creation of derivative works without permission, or authorization, of the former copyright owners.

The text encoding was created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and is governed by a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

note.p: This manuscript fragment regarding the importance of the spiritual aspect of human consciousness is probably part of a draft of "A Lingering Note" in "Notes (such as they are) founded on Elias Hicks." The essay was first published in November Boughs (1888). The leaf has been pasted to a backing sheet, rendering the verso inaccessible.

bibl.author: Whitman, Walt
bibl.title: The Consciences — the Moral one
bibl.orgName: Walt Whitman Literary Manuscripts in the Walt Whitman Collection, Harry Ransom Humanities Research Center at the University of Texas at Austin
bibl.note: Transcribed from digital images of the original.
The verso is inaccessible as the paper has been pasted to another sheet.

text.body:
The Consciences — the Moral one
We cannot pronounce too strongly,
the ‸evident need, (these times, These States, the of the realization among writers, teachers, lecturers, in fitting ways, from primary lessons upward.) of the realizationpromulgation, and developementcultivation among the consciences, ‸and the bringing to the front again, among the conciences. of & setting up. the greatest of all, yet apparently, most utterly neglected namelynamely the the ‸absolute, uncompromising moral. one. The intellectual &or
<pb xml:id="leaf001v" facs="" type="verso"/>
